metadata.title: Recommendations from the Sociedade Portuguesa de Cuidados Intensivos and Infection & Sepsis Group for intensive care approach to COVID-19

body_text.text: COVID-19, short for coronavirus disease 2019, is a clinical disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, a simple positive-sense RNA genome virus, belonging to the coronaviruses (CoV) family. There are four strains (HCoV-229E, HCoV-NL63, HCoV-OC43, and HCoV-HKU1) with seasonal circulation among human populations, most frequently causing mild-severity respiratory infections (such as common cold) and, rarely, viral pneumonia.(1) Before the emergence of SARS-CoV-2,(2) two strains causing epidemic outbreaks from zoonotic origin were described: SARS-CoV-1, causing severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) originated from bats and transmitted to the African civet, and later to humans in 2002; and MERS-CoV, causing the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) originated from bats, transmitted to camelids, and later, to humans in 2012.(1)
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: On December 31, 2019, a pneumonia cluster from an unknown cause was identified in the Chinese city of Wuhan (Hubei province), later associated with the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market. The respiratory samples from these patients lead to the identification of a new virus (SARS-CoV-2) with an epidemic dissemination throughout China and progressively spreading to multiple countries (mostly South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran),(3) and since March 2, to Portugal.(4) Its contagion capacity is due to a significant attack rate (R⌀, number of new cases generated from one single confirmed case) that has been estimated to be from 2.5 to 2.9, although potentially affected by public health interventions.(5) High risk of nosocomial transmission has been observed, as well as contamination of healthcare professionals.(6)
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The median incubation time is four days, but it may last until 14 days,(6) and the SARS-CoV-2, similar to SARS-CoV-1, links to angiotensin 2 converting enzyme receptors located on type II alveolar cells, causing diffuse alveolar and direct cytopathic injury.(7) Most of the infected patients (> 80%) present with mild disease, with no need for admission to the hospital. Among those admitted to the hospital, 6% to 10% require referral to intensive care.(3,6)
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: These recommendations are aimed to support the organization of intensive care services to respond to COVID-19, providing optimized care for patients and protection of healthcare professionals.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It is recommended to adapt the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for definition of clinical syndromes associated with COVID-19 (Attachment 1).
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 1. CLINICAL SYNDROMES ASSOCIATED WITH COVID-19

body_text.text: It is recommended that patients with criteria for severe pneumonia (Attachment 1) are early referred to intensive care services, in order to discuss the decision and timing for referring to the intensive care service.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 2. CRITERIA FOR ADMISSION TO INTENSIVE CARE SERVICES

body_text.text: It is recommended that admission to intensive care is not based on strict criteria, but on case-by-case assessment, each time including perception of severity by the clinician and global management of the available resources.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 2. CRITERIA FOR ADMISSION TO INTENSIVE CARE SERVICES

body_text.text: It is recommended that, in case of extreme lack of resources, explicit priority admission criteria to intensive care are in place.
body_text.section: Recommendation 3 ::: 2. CRITERIA FOR ADMISSION TO INTENSIVE CARE SERVICES

body_text.text: Isolation in individual rooms with negative pressure and gates, privative toilet and ventilation system with capacity for 6 - 12 air changes per hour. Once exhausted these resources, patients are recommended to be isolated in individual rooms with a ventilation system with capacity for 6 - 12 air changes per hour. When no isolation individual rooms are available, cohort isolation is recommended, keeping a minimum distance of 1 meter between patients’ units.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: Visits restriction is recommended for all patients and limiting the number of professionals in contact with the patient (ideally, dedicated professionals), implementing alternative remote ways for communication between patient and family, and the clinical team, patient and family, independent of the isolation site.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: All healthcare professionals involved in clinical care are recommended to use universal precautions, contact precautions, and droplet precautions. These include wearing specific individual protection equipment, disposable (one use) and impermeable coat, surgical mask, eye protection, and clean gloves. During potentially generating aerosols care (e.g. intubation, aspiration of secretions and bronchoscopy), or prolonged contact (> 15 minutes), and/or close contact (e.g. placing central venous catheter, surgery, cardiorespiratory reanimation maneuvers), airway precautions are recommended. These include wearing specific individual protection equipment, disposable (one use) and impermeable: coat (with long sleeve and elastic cuff, and covering until the mid of legs or ankles), cap, FFP2/FFP3 mask (appropriately fit to the face), eye protection (with lateral protection), gloves (reaching above the coat sleeves), and shoe protection (ideally impermeable shoes for exclusive use on the isolation area or impermeable shoe protection). It is recommended that the integral protection outfit (impermeable, including hat and neck protection) is limited to trained professionals with practical experience in their use. Once the use of nebulizers, noninvasive mechanic ventilation, and high-flow nasal cannulas are potential aerosol generators, airway protection measures are recommended to be equally used during the clinical care of these patients.
body_text.section: Recommendation 3 ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: Order and technic for putting on and removing individual protection equipment should be strictly adhered to (ideally using a mirror or observation by another healthcare professional). Particularly during removal, it is recommended additional care to prevent self-contamination and contamination other people and the environment.
body_text.section: Recommendation 4 ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: It is recommended that all healthcare professionals are trained and have practical experience putting on and removing individual protection equipment before any contact with patients.
body_text.section: Recommendation 5 ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: We followed the recommendations from the Portuguese General Health Management(8) based on WHO(9) and European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC)(10) on strategies for prevent and control SARS-CoV-2 infection mainly on the prevention of transmission in healthcare facilities, based on recommendations previously issued for MERSCoV1 and SARS-CoV1.
body_text.section: Rational ::: 3. ISOLATION AND INDIVIDUAL PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

body_text.text: It is recommended the Intensive Care Service management to manage all hospital level 2 (intermediate) and level 3 (intensive) beds, (independently of the service they are located) in close cooperation with the Clinical Director, General Health Management and the Ministry of Health.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 4. HOSPITAL ORGANIZATION

body_text.text: It is recommended that, in hospitals with more than one intensive care unit, a cohort area is set for confirmed COVID-19 critical patients, and to consider setting a cohort area for suspected critical patients (for temporary stay), and criteria for its activation are established.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 4. HOSPITAL ORGANIZATION

body_text.text: It is recommended that the microbiologic diagnosis use a real-time polymerase chain reaction test (real-time PCR) to analyze samples from upper airways (swabs of nasopharynx and oropharynx exudates), whenever possible associated with a lower respiratory tract sample (bronchial secretions collected from endotracheal aspirate).
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 5. INFECTION DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: It is not recommended to perform bronchoscopy exclusively to collect samples from the lower respiratory tract.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 5. INFECTION DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: Whenever there is high clinical suspicion (especially if a computed tomography scan shows disease evidence) and microbiologic testing is negative, it is recommended to repeat the test to either confirm or rollout infection, preferably with samples from the lower respiratory tract.
body_text.section: Recommendation 3 ::: 5. INFECTION DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: Blood culture samples are recommended (at least two blood culture sets, aerobic and anaerobic) and a sample from the lower respiratory tract to search for other microbiologic agents.
body_text.section: Recommendation 4 ::: 5. INFECTION DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: Real-time PCR test (RT-PCR) is a highly specific test to identify the presence of SARS-CoV-2, and patients with greater viral load (most frequently during the disease) may be more likely to show a positive test. However, for patients with suspected COVID-19 and a negative RT-PCR test, repeating the test was positive in 23% of the cases (conversion over time), pointing to a sensitivity lower than 80%. In these cases, whenever possible a chest computed tomography scan should be performed, searching for disease evidence before real-time PCR.(11,12) Coinfection with other microbiological agents, especially in the event of a septic shock, is frequent.(11
body_text.section: Rational ::: 5. INFECTION DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: All severe pneumonia patients are recommended to receive oxygen therapy, started with 4L/minute nasal cannula and titrated to oxygen saturation (SpO2) ≥ 92%, without humidification.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 6. INITIAL THERAPY FOR SUSPECTED/CONFIRMED CASES

body_text.text: A conservative fluid therapy strategy is recommended, especially in the absence of shock.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 6. INITIAL THERAPY FOR SUSPECTED/CONFIRMED CASES

body_text.text: We adhered to WHO recommendations,(13) highlighting that no humidification is required for oxygen flows < 4L/minute(14) and that the use of bubble humidifiers with oxygen flows ≥ 5L/minute produces aerosols that increase the risk of transmitting microorganisms.(15) The initial presentation of COVID-19 is rarely of a septic shock, and the most frequent cause of death is hypoxemic respiratory failure,(16) aggravated by inappropriate fluid therapy.(17
body_text.section: Rational ::: 6. INITIAL THERAPY FOR SUSPECTED/CONFIRMED CASES

body_text.text: It is recommended not to use high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy in patients during the active viral replication phase.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 7. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR HIGH-FLOW NASAL CANNULA OXYGEN THERAPY

body_text.text: It is recommended that, if a decision to start a high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy is made:
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 7. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR HIGH-FLOW NASAL CANNULA OXYGEN THERAPY

body_text.text: (1) that the technique is started at the intensive care service in a highly monitored environment, allowing to prevent delaying intubation in cases of failure to respond;(2) that low flows are preferred (15 - 30L/minute), with the patient wearing a surgical mask (whenever possible); and(3) that healthcare professionals use contact precautions for droplets and airway (ideally in negative pressure rooms).
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 7. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR HIGH-FLOW NASAL CANNULA OXYGEN THERAPY

body_text.text: Nasal cannula high-flow oxygen therapy has been successfully used in hypoxemic respiratory failure patients,(18) however it can potentially delay endotracheal intubation(19) and increase the risk of aerosols generation.(20
body_text.section: Rational ::: 7. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR HIGH-FLOW NASAL CANNULA OXYGEN THERAPY

body_text.text: In these patients it is recommended not to use noninvasive ventilation, especially during the viral active replication phase.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 8. NONINVASIVE VENTILATION: INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY

body_text.text: It is recommended that, if a decision to start noninvasive ventilation is made:
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 8. NONINVASIVE VENTILATION: INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY

body_text.text: (1) it is started at the intensive care service under intensive monitorization, preventing delays of endotracheal intubation in case of failure to respond;(2) to use maximal sealing masks or helmets, as well double-circuit ventilators (e.g. with an expiratory loop) with a high-efficiency application; and(3) the healthcare professionals use contact precautions, both for droplets and airways (ideally in negative pressure rooms).
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 8. NONINVASIVE VENTILATION: INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY

body_text.text: Results of noninvasive ventilation are worse than conventional oxygen therapy, and high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy in patients with hypoxemic respiratory failure,(18) and was associated with increased therapeutic failure in patients with MERS,(21) as well as it leads to an increased risk of generating aerosols.(20,22
body_text.section: Rational ::: 8. NONINVASIVE VENTILATION: INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY

body_text.text: An early intubation strategy is recommended as opposed to a late intubation strategy (Figure 1).
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 9. INDICATIONS FOR OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION
Recommendation 1 ::: 9. INDICATIONS FOR OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION

body_text.text: In a context of hypoxemic respiratory failure, a delay in endotracheal intubation is associated with increased mortality(23) as previously observed in COVID-19 patients.(20)
body_text.section: Rational ::: 9. INDICATIONS FOR OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION

body_text.text: It is recommended that endotracheal intubation is performed by an experienced professional (who is more likely to succeed in a first attempt), wearing contact precautions for droplets and airway (ideally in a negative pressure room).
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 10. OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION STRATEGY

body_text.text: It is recommended that endotracheal intubation is performed using:
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 10. OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION STRATEGY

body_text.text: (1) pre-oxygenation with a high-concentration facial mask or a Mapleson C type balloon, connected to a high-efficiency respiratory filter, always avoiding manual inflations;(2) rapid sequence intubation technique;(3) video laryngoscopy using a disposable blade;(4) after intubation, clamping the tube until connection to a manual ventilator (or a Mapleson C type balloon) or to the mechanical ventilator adapted to a high efficiency filter;(5) confirm the intubation by capnography/capnometry followed by chest X-ray (no auscultation).
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 10. OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION STRATEGY

body_text.text: Endotracheal intubation is associated with a clear risk of generating aerosols,(20,22) and all strategies should be in place to minimize the risk of transmission to the healthcare professionals.(24
body_text.section: Rational ::: 10. OROTRACHEAL INTUBATION STRATEGY

body_text.text: A classic ventilation strategy is recommended, based on the Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Network protocol (tidal volume of 6mL/kg ideal body weight, with an upper limit for plateau pressures < 30cmH2O), using a table for high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in patients with moderate to severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), associated with a driving pressure < 15cmH2O and a respiratory rate to maintain pH > 7.25.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 11. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR INVASIVE MECHANIC VENTILATION AND THERAPEUTIC ADJUVANTS

body_text.text: It is recommended early prone position ventilation in patients with partial oxygen pressure/fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) < 150mmHg, for minimum 16 hours periods.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 11. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR INVASIVE MECHANIC VENTILATION AND THERAPEUTIC ADJUVANTS

body_text.text: Neuromuscular blockers are recommended to be used for ≤ 48 hours in patients with PaO2/FiO2 < 150mmHg.
body_text.section: Recommendation 3 ::: 11. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR INVASIVE MECHANIC VENTILATION AND THERAPEUTIC ADJUVANTS

body_text.text: In patients with active viral replication, it is recommended that spontaneous breathing test, when indicated, is performed with support pressure using a closed circuit, instead of a T tube.
body_text.section: Recommendation 4 ::: 11. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR INVASIVE MECHANIC VENTILATION AND THERAPEUTIC ADJUVANTS

body_text.text: We adhere to the WHO(13) recommendations, highlighting the strategies shown effective in ARDS.(25-28
body_text.section: Rational ::: 11. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR INVASIVE MECHANIC VENTILATION AND THERAPEUTIC ADJUVANTS

body_text.text: It is recommended adherence to current criteria for referral to extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), based on a case-by-case assessment, including the perception of severity by the clinician and overall resources management.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 12. INDICATIONS FOR EXTRACORPOREAL MEMBRANE OXYGENATION

body_text.text: In case of an extraordinary scarcity of resources, it is recommended to explicit the criteria for referral to ECMO.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 12. INDICATIONS FOR EXTRACORPOREAL MEMBRANE OXYGENATION

body_text.text: ECMO is therapy to be considered in a context of refractory hypoxemic respiratory failure,(29) but, although already in use, its benefit in COVID-19 is still unclear.(30
body_text.section: Rational ::: 12. INDICATIONS FOR EXTRACORPOREAL MEMBRANE OXYGENATION

body_text.text: It is recommended not to perform bronchial fibroscopy, except for well-established indications.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 13. INDICATIONS FOR BRONCHIAL FIBROSCOPY

body_text.text: It is recommended that, if a decision for a bronchial fibroscopy is made, it should be performed by the most experienced professional wearing airway precautions (in negative pressure rooms).
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 13. INDICATIONS FOR BRONCHIAL FIBROSCOPY

body_text.text: Bronchial fibroscopy is associated with a clear risk of generating aerosols(22), and all strategies should be in place to minimize the risk of transmission to healthcare professionals.(11
body_text.section: Rational ::: 13. INDICATIONS FOR BRONCHIAL FIBROSCOPY

body_text.text: When clinically indicated, it is recommended inhalation therapy not to be performed using pneumatic, ultrasonic or oscillatory membrane devices.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 14. INHALATION THERAPY

body_text.text: Inhalation therapy using pneumatic, ultrasonic or oscillatory membrane devices is associated with a clear risk of generating aerosols(22), and all strategies should be in place to minimize the risk of transmission to healthcare professionals.(11
body_text.section: Rational ::: 14. INHALATION THERAPY

body_text.text: It is recommended to avoid the administration of corticosteroids, unless if indicated for other reasons (e.g. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation or septic shock, according to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines).
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 15. INDICATION FOR CORTICOSTEROID THERAPY

body_text.text: Current evidence point to a lack of corticosteroids benefit on mortality, causing delayed viral clearance in patients infected with SARS-CoV-1 e MERS-CoV.(31,32
body_text.section: Rational ::: 15. INDICATION FOR CORTICOSTEROID THERAPY

body_text.text: In case of severe pneumonia (while waiting for SARS-CoV-2 identification) in times of seasonal influenza, in association with antibiotic therapy to start to start influenza therapy (Table 1), to be reassessed after laboratory tests and culture are available.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 16. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY

body_text.text: It is recommended that in case of severe pneumonia (with identified SARS-CoV-2) with a septic shock, to start antibiotic therapy until culture results are available, allowing to confirm or rule out coexisting bacterial infection.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 16. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY

body_text.text: It is recommended that, in case of severe pneumonia (with identified SARS-CoV-2), in the absence of a septic shock, starting antibiotic therapy to be decided on a case-by-case basis and reconsidered in case of negative results.
body_text.section: Recommendation 3 ::: 16. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY

body_text.text: Coinfection with other microbiological agents, especially in case of a septic shock, is frequent.(11) Mortality associated with septic shock is high and associated with a delayed start of effective antibiotic therapy.(33
body_text.section: Rational ::: 16. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY FOR ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY

body_text.text: There is no evidence from randomized controlled trials to recommend any specific antiviral therapy for COVID-19 patients.
body_text.section: Recommendation 1 ::: 17. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY OF ANTIVIRAL THERAPY

body_text.text: Experimental therapy (Table 2) may be considered for patients with clinical criteria for severity.
body_text.section: Recommendation 2 ::: 17. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY OF ANTIVIRAL THERAPY

body_text.text: No antiviral therapy was proven effective for COVID-19. Several randomized controlled trials are ongoing.(34) Limited evidence is available for the use of lopinavir/ritonavir,(35,36) chloroquine(37) and remdesivir,(38,39) that were included in the Italian therapy protocol.(40) Retrospective data on SARS-CoV point to higher efficacy of early started therapy (< 48 hours),(35) however efficacy after this time is not ruled out, consistent with data for influenza virus infection.
body_text.section: Rational ::: 17. INDICATIONS AND STRATEGY OF ANTIVIRAL THERAPY

AST - aspartate aminotransferase; ALT - alanine aminotransferase; FiO2 - fraction of inspired oxygen; PEEP - positive end-expiratory pressure; HCFM - high-concentration face mask; ECMO - extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.
